I used the cream for 3 months . Apply the cream morning n night for 15 min daily. Reduce going out and getting your face covered with dirt.

But your diet affect your hormones. For example if you eat low glychemical index foods such as vegetables your insulin lowers which makes your testosteron levels lower which affects sebum levels in the skin. Genetics plays a role in how hormone levels affect us. Avoiding fat foods though has no affect on the level of sebum created in your skin.

Contraceptives work against pimples in some cases because they contain high levels of estrogen in them. Estrogen ties testosterone levels down. In women with pcos the levels of a type of protein in the blood that ties down testosterone is lower than in women without pcos. Women with pcos are told that contraceptives is the only treatment available for pcos but changing your food intake to low GI has been scientifically proven to decrease the symptoms of pcos.

That is because low GI foods lower insulin, testosterone and when testosterone levels go down fertility goes up and all those problems with pimples, too much hair growth and so on disappears or radically decreases for women with pcos.

Acne, pimples, blackheads...if you have these, try a 2% salicylic acid toner like Neutrogena's (my fave). I've had terrible issues with acne my whole life but since i be started using this toner on my face, neck, and chest, I no longer have to worry about these things! And if I see a pimple beginning to show, I hit it hard with the toner and overnight, the inflammation and redness have damn near fled the city of my face. Fair warning, it BURN when you use it, so if you have never used salicylic acid or have sensitive skin, start out w. a lower % of the acid. They have .5, 1, and 2% available OTC in various forms but I suggest a toner, not a face wash, as the wash doesn't give the acid enough time to dig deep into those pores. Its also an excellent exfoliant, so you can ditch your exfoliant while using. Exfoliating with this toner also helps to speed up cell turnover which equals healthier, more elastic skin that is less inclined to break out, assuming you use it in your regimen enough. I can't tell you how much this little product has changed my life. It even works on chest and back, and as a woman, I can't say how relieved I am to not have to worry about acne on my goddamn chest like I'm a pubescent 14 yr old male. Do give it a try. Everyone's skin is different, so this may not be your end-all cure, but it sure was mine.

if you frequently get acne on your forehead, it could be because of:

1) irregular sleeping schedule
2) poor diet
3) digestive system issues

to fix this, or attempt to make it better, try going to bed before eleven every night, and eat healthier foods, until you see improvement.



if you frequently get acne on your chin, this could be because of a kidney imbalance, or a hormonal imbalance.



if you get acne on your cheeks a lot, this could be caused by stress, or allergies. so, try to avoid situations that stress you out, or figure out of you have any allergies.


acne or blackheads on your nose could be a result of poor blood circulation.

In conclusion acne is treatable  through medication/ organic treatments, and a clean life style (grooming/washing), controlling stress levels (stress increases hormone production, example cortisol). To say diet has little to do with acne is misguided. Hormonal balance can only be achieved with certain diet. Radical diet changes significantly effect acne. Just because there has not been enough research on acne and diet does not mean there is no relation. Actually, one study has shown how effective eliminating dairy can be for preventing acne. (this is due to hormones and insulin spiking effects from dairy.) Other foods to avoid are oils with Polyunsaturated omega 6 fatty acids and trans fats like Canola, soybean, sunflower, safflower, and corn oils. (replace with monounsaturated fats like coconut and red palm oils.) This will rebalance the ratio of omega 6's to 3's which reduces inflammation and oxidation (two key factors of acne.) Eliminating sugar (except fruit) reduces inflammation, decreases insulin resistance (insulin is a known acne causing hormone), and takes away the source of food for malicious bacteria colonizations and candida in the gut. Gut microbiota plays a major role in creating hormones in the intestines which are absorbed. There are so many causes of acne, many indirectly caused by diet, that is why science has not yet succeeded at finding a strong link between acne and the foods we eat. This is why diet is too often overlooked as a solution to clearing skin. The best way to find dietary acne triggers are to eliminate foods you may be allergic to, as well as all dairy, sugar (except whole fruits), grains, and the aforementioned omega 6 oils. Once the skin is clear, reintroduce until acne reappears. Then you will know which foods cause acne for you personally.

Diet actually can play a part.  But not in the myth way people say like oily, greasy foods causes oily skin.  No.  Rather it's eating the right foods that your body can help fight pimples better.  Granted it's a case by case scenario and it can be difficult to find which foods make it better or worsen it.  There is some evidence that Zinc can help control the sebum levels.  So it's the nutrient density in food that can possibly help some acne sufferers.  There are so many factors that play into skin health like the chemicals in our shampoos, the pesticides in our foods, etc.
My diet change has greatly improved my skin, though. You are what you eat and your skin is a showcase of your health!

It's true that acne is a bacterial infection and I find it interesting that people without acne have the same bacteria on their face but just a different strain. but diet (feed your face by dr.jessica wu)  and lifestyle (stress, exercise, and hygiene) definitely play a major role. Also, exercising can help b/c it helps lower the amount of cortisol (stress hormone) in your body. But if you don't wash away the sweat, that can clog your pores. Also, diet can affect your skin. I don't have any studies off the top of my head to prove this but I feel like Pro Active and this video really over look diet and life style like sleep. There seems to be a high prevalence in statements when it comes to acne like  "I can't do anything aboutit ", "I'm born predisposed",  and "It's not your fault you need to buy our product". Maybe I've just been surrounded by a different genetic makeup of individuals in the regions I live, regions like Seattle and Kansas City. For me personally and those I've given suggestions to have always had huge success when it comes to changing diet and lifestyle. Reducing sugars (both natural and un-natural), drinking more water, eating more vegetables and fruit (mainly vegetables), and one biggy for me get enough sleep on a constant sleep schedule. I have had fairly severe acne for a decade since I hit puberty. Used a varying amount of products during that time with little results. For general health reason, not really for acne at the time since I had kind of given up finding a cure, I wanted to improve my diet and exercise more. I completely changed my lifestyle of eating out everyday at fast foods and started cooking at home. Lots of stir fry at first lol. But heavy with vegetables and little meat. Made smoothies every morning with things like spinach, banana, honey, coconut, avocado, almond milk, chia seeds, blueberries, pineapple, and strawberries. Only drank water, with the occasional juice. And actually that hardest thing, but one of the more effective, was going to bed at consistent time, and for me close to 8hrs a night. It still took a few months to see results but after a few months my acne dramatically reduced. It's been a couple years since and I only get small occasional breakouts, usually when I go out and eat lol. I've discussed this with quite a few people in my years since and the ones who adopt similar lifestyle changes see the similar results. Guess I should do a case study ;). So I don't know but from my perspective with me and the people in my region diet seems to have a great impact on acne. Through, funny enough, a process I think we should be doing anyway for just our general health let alone acne.
